div0.head: Ν

div1.head: ναέτης
div1.sense: an inhabitant, Simon.; as fem., Anth.

div1.head: Ναϊακός
div1.sense: of or for the Naiads, Anth.

div1.head: Ναϊάς
div1.sense: a Naiad, a river nymph, (as Νηρηίς is a sea-nymph), mostly in pl. Ναϊάδες, Ionic Νηϊάδες, Od., Eur.:—so also Ionic Νηίς, ίδος, in sg., Il., Eur.

div1.head: ναιετάω
div1.sense: of persons, to dwell, often in Hom. and Hes.
c. acc. loci, to dwell in, inhabit, Hom., Hes.
of places, to be situated, lie, Hom.: hence to exist, Ἰθάκης ἔτι ναιεταούσης Il.

div1.head: ναί
div1.sense: used in strong affirmation, yea, verily, Lat. nae, Hom., Attic; in Hom. mostly followed by δή.
ναὶ μά in oaths, yea by . . , ναὶ μὰ τόδε σκῆπτρον Il.; μά is sometimes omitted, ναὶ τὰν κόραν Ar.; ναὶ πρὸς θεῶν Eur.
in answers, alone, aye, yes, τοῦτʼ ἐτήτυμον; answ. ναί Aesch.; ναί, ναί Ar.

div1.head: ναίχι
div1.etym: adverb for ναί, like οὐχί for οὐ, Soph.

div1.head: ναίω
div1.sense: of persons, to dwell, abide, Il., Hes., Trag.:—c. acc loci, to dwell in, inhabit, οἶκον, δῶμα, ἅλα, etc., Hom., etc.:—Pass. to be inhabited, Theocr.
of places, to lie, be situated, Soph.
Causal, in Epic aor1 ἔνασσα or νάσσα,
c. acc. loci, to give one to dwell in, νάσσα πόλιν I would have given him a town for his home, Od.: also to make habitable, to build, νηὸν ἔνασσαν Hhymn.:—Pass., v. εὐναιόμενος.
c. acc. pers. to let one dwell, settle him, Pind.; Pass., Epic aor1 νάσθην, to be settled, to dwell, Il.; so, aor1 mid., νάσσατο ἄγχι Ἑλικῶνος Hes.; perf. νένασται Anth.
div1.head: ναίω
div1.sense: to run over, to be full, Od.

div1.head: νάκη
div1.sense: a wooly or hairy skin, a goatskin, Od.

div1.head: νάκος
div1.sense: a fleece, Lat. vellus, Hdt., Pind., etc.

div1.head: νᾶμα
div1.sense: anything flowing, running water, a river, stream, Trag., Plat.

div1.head: νᾶνος
div1.sense: a dwarf, Ar.

div1.head: νανοφυής
div1.sense: of dwarfish stature, Ar.

div1.head: Νάξιος
div1.sense: Naxian; οἱ N. the Naxians, Hdt.; Ναξία ἀκόνα a Naxian whetstone, Pind.

div1.head: Ναξιουργής
div1.sense: of Naxian work, Ar.

div1.head: Νάξος
div1.sense: Naxos, one of the Cyclades, Hhymn.

div1.head: ναοπόλος
div1.sense: the overseer of a temple, Hes.

div1.head: ναός
div1.sense: the dwelling of a god, a temple, Hom., Hdt., etc.
the inmost part of a temple, the cell, in which the image of the god was placed, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: ναοφύλαξ
div1.sense: the keeper of a temple, Lat. aedituus, Eur., Arist.

div1.head: ναπαῖος
div1.sense: of a wooded vale or dell, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: νάπη
div1.sense: a wooded vale, dell, or glen, Il., Soph.

div1.head: νάπος
div1.etym: later form of νάπη, Soph., Eur., Xen.

div1.head: νᾶπυ
div1.sense: = σίναπι; ν. βλέπειν Ar.; cf. κάρδαμον.

div1.head: ναρδολιπής
div1.sense: anointed with nard-oil, Anth.

div1.head: νάρδος
div1.sense: a plant, nard, spikenard, nard-oil, Anth.

div1.head: ναρθηκοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying a νάρθηξ, a wand-bearer, πολλοί τοι ναρθηκοφόροι, Βάκχοι δέ τε παῦροι, i. e. there are many officials, but few inspired, Plat.

div1.head: νάρθηξ
div1.sense: a tall umbelliferous plant, Lat. ferula, with a hollow, pithy stalk, in which Prometheus conveyed fire from heaven to earth, Hes. The stalks furnished the Bacchanalian wands (θύρσοι) , Eur., (cf. ναρθηκο-φόρος); they were also used for canes by schoolmasters, Xen.
a casket for unguents, Luc.

div1.head: ναρκάω
div1.sense: to grow stiff or numb, Lat. torpere, Il., Plat.

div1.head: νάρκη
div1.sense: numbness, deadness, Lat. torpor, Ar.
a flat fish, the torpedo or electric ray, Plat.

div1.head: νάρκισσος
div1.sense: the narcissus, Hhymn., Soph., etc.
div1.etym: From ναρκάω, because of its narcotic properties.

div1.head: νασμός
div1.sense: a flowing stream, a stream, Eur.

div1.head: νάσσω
div1.sense: to press or squeeze close, stamp down, Od., Theocr.

div1.head: ναστός
div1.sense: close- pressed: ναστός (sc. πλακοῦς) , a well-kneaded cake, cheese-cake, Ar.

div1.head: ναυαγέω
div1.sense: to suffer shipwreck, be shipwrecked, Hdt., Xen., etc.:—metaph. of chariots, to be wrecked, Dem.

div1.head: ναυαγία
div1.sense: shipwreck, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: ναυάγιον
div1.sense: a piece of wreck, Hdt., Aesch., Thuc.: metaph., ναυάγια ἱππικά the wreck of a chariot, Soph.
= ναυαγία, Strab.

div1.head: ναυαγός
div1.sense: shipwrecked, stranded, Lat. naufragus, Hdt., Eur.; ναυαγοὺς ἀναιρεῖσθαι to pick up the shipwrecked men, Xen.; ν. τάφος the grave of the shipwrecked, i. e. the sea, Anth.
act. causing shipwreck, ἄνεμοι Anth.

div1.head: ναυαρχέω
div1.sense: to command a fleet, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: ναυαρχία
div1.sense: the command of a fleet, office of ναύαρχος, Thuc.: the period of his command, Xen.

div1.head: ναυαρχίς
div1.sense: the ship of the ναύαρχος, Polyb.

div1.head: ναύαρχος
div1.sense: the commander of a fleet, an admiral, Hdt., Aesch., Soph.:—esp. the Spartan admiral-in-chief, whereas the Athen. admirals retained the name of στρατηγοί (generals), Thuc., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ναυβάτης
div1.sense: a "ship-goer," a seaman, Hdt., Aesch., Soph., etc.
as adj., ν. στρατός Aesch.; στόλος Soph., etc.

div1.head: ναύδετον
div1.sense: a shipʼs cable, Eur.

div1.head: ναυκληρέω
div1.sense: to be a shipowner, Ar., Xen.
metaph., ν. πόλιν to manage, govern, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: ναυκληρία
div1.sense: a seafaring life, ship-owning, Arist.
poet. a voyage, Eur.:— an adventure, enterprise, Eur.
a ship, Eur.

div1.head: ναυκλήριον
div1.sense: the ship of a ναύκληρος, Dem.
= ναύσταθμος, Eur.

div1.head: ναύκληρος
div1.sense: a shipowner, ship-master, Hdt., Soph., etc.
as adj., ν. χείρ the masterʼs hand, of a charioteer (cf. ἡνίοχος I. 3), Eur.

div1.head: ναύκραρος
div1.sense: at Athens, one of a division, of the citizens, made for financial purposes before Solonʼs time. There were 4 in each φρατρία, 12 in each of the 4 old φυλαί, in all 48, afterwards increased to 50. (Apparently an old form of ναύ-κληρος: but the connexion of the word with ναῦς ship is not explained.)

div1.head: ναυκρατέω
div1.sense: to be master of the sea, Thuc.:— Pass. to be mastered at sea, Xen.

div1.head: ναυκρατής
div1.sense: master or mistress of the seas, Hdt.

div1.head: Ναύκρατις
div1.sense: Naucratis in Egypt, Hdt.

div1.head: ναυκράτωρ
div1.sense: = ναυκρατής, Hdt., Thuc.
the master of a ship, Soph.

div1.head: ναῦλος
div1.sense: passage-money, the fare or freight, Xen.
the freight or cargo of ships, Dem.

div1.head: ναυλοχέω
div1.sense: to lie in a harbour or creek, esp. to lie in wait there in order to sally out on passing ships, Hdt., Eur.
c. acc. to lie in wait for, Thuc.

div1.head: ναύλοχος
div1.sense: affording safe anchorage, of a harbour, Od., Soph.; ὦ ναύλοχα καὶ πετραῖα λουτρά ye springs by the haven and from the rock (where some take ναύλοχα as Subst.) Soph.

div1.head: ναυμαχέω
div1.sense: to fight in a ship or by sea, engage in a naval battle, Hdt., Xen.; ν. τὴν περὶ τῶν κρεῶν to be in the battle for the carcases (i. e. Arginusae), Ar.
metaph. to do battle with, κακοῖς Ar.

div1.head: ναυμαχησείω
div1.sense: Desid., to wish to fight by sea, Thuc.

div1.head: ναυμαχητέος
div1.sense: one must fight by sea, Arist.

div1.head: ναυμαχία
div1.sense: a sea-fight, Hdt., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: ναύμαχος
div1.sense: of or for a sea-fight, ξυστὰ ναύμαχα boarding pikes, Il.; δόρατα Hdt.

div1.head: ναυμάχος
div1.sense: act. fighting at sea, Anth.

div1.head: Ναύπακτος
div1.sense: a city on the north of the gulf of Corinth, Thuc.

div1.head: ναυπηγέω
div1.sense: to build ships, Ar., Plat.: —Mid., ναῦς ναυπηγέεσθαι to build oneself ships, get them built, Hdt., Attic:—Pass., of ships, to be built, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: ναυπηγήσιμος
div1.sense: useful in shipbuilding, of wood, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: ναυπηγία
div1.sense: shipbuilding, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: ναυπηγικός
div1.sense: skilled in shipbuilding, Luc.: ἡ ναυπηγική (sc. τέχνη) the art of shipbuilding, Arist.

div1.head: ναυπήγιον
div1.sense: a shipbuilderʼs-yard, dockyard, Ar.

div1.head: ναυπηγός
div1.sense: a shipwright, Thuc., Plat.

div1.head: Ναυπλία
div1.sense: Nauplia in Argolis, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Ναυπλιεύς
div1.sense: a Nauplian, Strab. :— Ναύπλιος, or -έιος, η, ον, Eur.

div1.head: ναύπορος
div1.sense: of a country, ship-frequented, Aesch.

div1.head: ναυπόρος
div1.sense: ship-speeding, of oars, Eur.

div1.head: ναυσθλόω
div1.sense: to carry by sea, Eur.:—Mid. to take with one by sea, Eur.:—Pass. to go by sea, Eur.

div1.head: ναυσικλειτός
div1.sense: famed for ships, Od.

div1.head: ναυσικλυτός
div1.etym: = ναυσῐπέρᾱτος, epith. of the Phaeacians, Od.

div1.head: ναυσιπέρατος
div1.sense: navigable or (perhaps) to be crossed by a ferry, Hdt.

div1.head: ναυσίπομπος
div1.sense: act. ship-wafting, Eur.

div1.head: ναυσίπορος
div1.sense: traversed by ships, navigable, of a river, Xen.

div1.head: ναυσιπόρος
div1.sense: act. passing in a ship, seafaring, Eur.
causing a ship to pass, of oars, Eur.

div1.head: ναυσίστονος
div1.sense: lamentable to ships, Pind.

div1.head: ναυσιφόρητος
div1.sense: carried by ship, seafaring, Pind.

div1.head: ναῦς
div1.sense: a ship, Hom., etc.; ἐν νήεσσι or ἐν νηυσίν at the ships, i. e. in the camp formed by the ships drawn up on shore, Il.; νῆες μακραί, Lat. naves longae, ships of war, which were built long for speed, while the merchant-vessels (νῆες στρόγγυλαι, γαῦλοι, ὁλκάδες) were round-built, Hdt., etc

div1.head: ναύσταθμον
div1.sense: a harbour, anchorage, roadstead, Lat. statio navium, Eur., Thuc., Plut.

div1.head: ναυστολέω
div1.sense: trans. to carry or convey by sea, Eur.:—Pass., with fut. mid. -ήσομαι, to go by sea, Eur.
to guide, steer, Aesch., Eur.: metaph., τὼ πτέρυγε ποῖ ναυστολεῖς; whither pliest thou thy wings? Ar.
intr. like Pass. to go by ship, sail, Soph., Eur.
generally, c. acc. loci, to travel over, Eur.

div1.head: ναυστόλημα
div1.sense: anything conveyed by ship: in pl. also = ναυστολία, πόντου ναυστολήματα Eur.

div1.head: ναυστολία
div1.sense: a going by sea, naval expedition, Eur.

div1.head: ναύστολος
div1.sense: crossing the water, Aesch.

div1.head: ναύτης
div1.sense: Lat. nauta, a seaman, sailor, Hom., Hes., etc.; as adj., ν. ὅμιλος Eur.
a mate or companion by sea, ναύτην ἄγειν τινά Soph.

div1.head: ναυτία
div1.sense: seasickness, qualmishness, disgust, Lat. nausea, Simon.

div1.head: ναυτιάω
div1.sense: to be qualmish, suffer from seasickness or nausea, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: ναυτικός
div1.sense: seafaring, naval, ὁ ν. στρατός opp. to ὁ πεζός, Hdt.; ν. λεώς Aesch.; στόλος Soph.; ν. ἐρείπια wrecks of ships, Aesch.; ν. ἀναρχία among the seamen, Eur.:— τὸ ναυτικόν a navy, fleet, Hdt., Ar., etc.
of persons, skilled in seamanship, nautical, ναυτικοὶ ἐγένοντο became a naval power, Thuc.
ἡ ναυτική (sc. τέχνη) navigation, seamanship, Hdt.; so, τὰ ναυτικά Plat.;—but, τὰ ναυτικά, also, naval affairs naval power, Thuc., Xen.
at Athens, ναυτικόν technically meant money borrowed or lent on bottomry, Xen., etc.

div1.head: ναυτιλία
div1.sense: sailing, seamanship, Od., Hes.
a voyage, Pind., Hdt.
a ship, Anth.

div1.head: ναυτίλλομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to sail, go by sea, Hdt.; rare in Attic

div1.head: ναυτίλος
div1.sense: a seaman, sailor, Hdt., Aesch., etc.
as adj., ναυτίλος, ον, of a ship, Aesch.
the nautilus, a shell-fish, furnished with a membrane which serves it for a sail, Arist.

div1.head: ναυτολογέω
div1.sense: to take on board; metaph., Anth.

div1.head: ναυτολόγος
div1.sense: collecting seamen, Strab.

div1.head: ναυφθορία
div1.sense: shipwreck, loss of ships, Anth.

div1.head: ναύφθορος
div1.sense: shipwrecked, ν. στολή, πέπλοι the garb of shipwrecked men, Eur.

div1.head: ναύφρακτος
div1.sense: ship-fenced, Aesch., Eur.; στρατός Ar.:— ναύφρακτον βλέπειν to look like a ship of war, Ar.

div1.head: νάω
div1.etym: prob. only in pres. and imperf. :
div1.sense: to flow, Hom.

div1.head: νεάγγελτος
div1.sense: newly or lately told, Aesch.

div1.head: νεάζω
div1.sense: only in pres., intr. to be young or new, Aesch.; τὸ νεάζον youth, Soph.; νεάζων thinking or acting like a youth, Eur.
to be the younger of two, ὁ μὲν νεάζων Soph.
to grow young, Anth.

div1.head: νεαίρετος
div1.sense: newly taken, Aesch.

div1.head: νεακόνητος
div1.sense: newly-whetted, Soph.

div1.head: νεαλής
div1.sense: young, fresh, Xen., Plat.
of fish, fresh, Dem.

div1.head: νεάλωτος
div1.sense: newly caught, Hdt.

div1.head: νεανθής
div1.sense: new-blown, Anth.

div1.head: νεανίευμα
div1.sense: a youthful, i. e. a spirited or (in bad sense) a wanton act or word, Plat., etc.

div1.head: νεανιεύομαι
div1.sense: Dep., to act like a hot-headed youth, to act wantonly, to brawl, swagger, Plat.; τοιοῦτον ν. to make such youthful promises, Dem.:—c. inf. to undertake with youthful spirit, Plut.:—Pass., ἐφʼ ἅπασι τοῖς ἑαυτῷ νενεανιευμένοις to all his wanton acts, Dem.

div1.head: νεανίας
div1.sense: a young man, youth, with ἀνήρ, Od.; so, παῖς νεηνίης Hdt.; alone, like νεανίσκος, Soph., Eur., etc.
youthful, i. e. in good sense, impetuous, brave, active, Eur., Ar., etc.; or in bad sense, hot-headed, headstrong, Eur., Dem.
of things, new, young, fresh, Eur.

div1.head: νεανικός
div1.sense: youthful, fresh, active, vigorous, Ar.; ν. κρέας a fine large piece, Ar.
high-spirited, impetuous, dashing, generous, gay, τὸ νεανικώτατον the gayest, most dashing feat, Ar.; so, ν. καὶ μεγαλοπρεπεῖς τὰς διανοίας Plat.; μέγα καὶ νεανικὸν φρόνημα Dem.
in bad sense, headstrong, wanton, insolent, Plat.
of things, vehement, mighty, Eur., Arist.
adv. νεανικῶς, vigorously, Ar.
violently, wantonly, τύπτειν, τωθάζειν Ar.

div1.head: νεανισκεύομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to be in oneʼs youth, Xen.

div1.head: νεανίσκος
div1.sense: a youth, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: νεᾶνις
div1.sense: a young woman, girl, maiden, Il., Trag.; of a young married woman, Eur.
as adj. youthful, Eur.
new, Anth.

div1.head: νεαοιδός
div1.sense: singing youthfully, Anth.

div1.head: Νεάπολις
div1.sense: a new city, prop. n. of several cities (like our Newtown), esp. Neapolis, Naples.

div1.head: νεαρός
div1.sense: young, youthful, Il., Trag.; νεαροί youths, Aesch.;— τὸ ν. youthful spirit, Xen.
of things, new, fresh, νεαρὰ ἐξευρεῖν Pind.; ν. μυελός Aesch.
of events, new, recent, Soph.
adv. -ρῶς, youthfully, rawly, Luc.

div1.head: νεάτη
div1.sense: sc. χορδή the lowest of the three strings which formed the old musical scale (the other two being ἡ μέση and ἡ ὑπάτη) , Plat.

div1.head: νέατος
div1.etym: a poet. Sup. of νέος, as μέσατος of μέσος
div1.sense: the last, uttermost, lowest, Hom.; ὑπαὶ πόδα νείατον Ἴδης at the lowest slope of Ida, Il.:—c. gen., πόλις νεάτη Πύλου a city on the border of Pylos, Il.
of Time, latest, last, Soph.; τίς ἄρα νέατος λήξει, i. e. ὥστε νέατος γενέσθαι, Soph.; νέατον as adv. for the last time, Eur.

div1.head: νεατός
div1.sense: a ploughing up of fallow land, Xen.

div1.head: νεάω
div1.sense: to plough up anew, of fallow land, Lat. agros novare, Ar.:—Pass., νεωμένη (sc. γῆ) land new-ploughed, Lat. novale, Hes.

div1.head: νέβρειος
div1.sense: of a fawn, Anth.

div1.head: νεβριδόπεπλος
div1.sense: clad in fawnskin, Anth.

div1.head: νεβρίζω
div1.sense: to wear a fawnskin at the feast of Bacchus, or, as trans., to robe in fawnskins, Dem.

div1.head: νεβρίς
div1.sense: a fawnskin, esp. as the dress of Bacchus and the Bacchantes, Eur.

div1.head: νεβρός
div1.sense: the young of the deer, a fawn, Hom., etc.; πέδιλα νεβρῶν fawnskin brogues, Hdt.

div1.head: νεβρώδης
div1.sense: fawn-like, of Bacchus, Anth.

div1.head: νεηγενής
div1.sense: new-born, just born, Od.

div1.head: νεηθαλής
div1.sense: fresh-blown, young, Eur.

div1.head: νεήκης
div1.sense: newly whetted or sharpened, Il.

div1.head: νεήλατος
div1.sense: newly kneaded: νεήλατα, τά, new cakes, Dem.

div1.head: νέηλυς
div1.sense: newly come, a new-comer, Il., Hdt.

div1.head: νεήτομος
div1.sense: castrated when young, Anth.

div1.head: νεήφατος
div1.sense: new-sounding, Hhymn.

div1.head: νείαιρα
div1.etym: irreg. fem. comp. (cf. πρέσβειρα) of νέος, as νέατος, νείατος is Sup.
div1.sense: lower, νειαίρῃ δʼ ἐν γαστρί in the lower part of the belly, Il.

div1.head: νεικεστήρ
div1.sense: one who wrangles with another, c. gen., Hes.

div1.head: νεικέω
div1.sense: to quarrel or wrangle with one, c. dat., Il.:—absol., Hom.; part. νεικέων, obstinately, Hdt.
trans. to rail at, abuse, upbraid, revile, c. acc. pers., Hom.

div1.head: νεῖκος
div1.sense: a quarrel, wrangle, strife, Hom., Hdt., etc.
strife of words, railing, abuse, a taunt, reproach, Il., Hdt.
a strife at law, dispute before a judge, Od.
battle, fight, Hom.; ν. φυλόπιδος Od.; of dissensions between whole nations, νεῖκος πρὸς Καρχηδονίους Hdt.
cause of strife, matter of quarrel, Soph.

div1.head: Νειλαιεύς
div1.sense: from the Nile, Anth.

div1.head: Νειλογενής
div1.sense: Nile-born, Anth.

div1.head: Νειλομέτριον
div1.sense: a Nilometer, a rod graduated to shew the rise and fall of the Nile, Strab.

div1.head: Νειλόρυτος
div1.sense: watered by the Nile, Anth.

div1.head: Νεῖλος
div1.sense: the Nile, first in Hes.;—in Hom. the river is called Αἴγυπτος.

div1.head: Νειλωΐς
div1.sense: situated on the Nile, Anth.

div1.head: Νειλώτης
div1.sense: in or on the Nile:—fem., Νειλῶτις χθών the land of Nile, Aesch.

div1.head: νειόθεν
div1.sense: from the bottom, νειόθεν ἐκ κραδίης from the bottom of his heart, Il.

div1.head: νειόθι
div1.sense: at the bottom, δάκε νειόθι θυμόν it stung him to his heartʼs core, Hes.: c. gen., νειόθι λίμνης Il.

div1.head: νειοποιέω
div1.sense: to take a green crop off a field, by which it is freshened and prepared for corn, Xen.

div1.head: νειός
div1.sense: Lat. novale, new land, i. e. land ploughed up anew after being left fallow, fallow-land, Il.; νειὸς τρίπολος a thrice-ploughed fallow, Hom.: in Attic also νεός, Xen.

div1.head: νειοτομεύς
div1.sense: one who breaks up a fallow, Anth.

div1.head: νεκάς
div1.sense: a heap of slain, ἐν αἰνῇσιν νεκάδεσσιν (Epic dat. pl.) Il.

div1.head: νεκράγγελος
div1.sense: messenger of the dead, Luc.

div1.head: νεκραγωγέω
div1.sense: to conduct the dead, Luc.

div1.head: νεκρακαδήμεια
div1.sense: a school of the dead, Luc.

div1.head: νεκρικός
div1.sense: of or for the dead, Luc. adv. -κῶς, Luc.

div1.head: νεκροβαρής
div1.sense: laden with the dead, Anth.

div1.head: νεκροδέγμων
div1.sense: receiving the dead, Aesch.

div1.head: νεκροδοχεῖον
div1.sense: a cemetery, mausoleum, Luc.

div1.head: νεκροκορίνθια
div1.sense: the cinerary urns dug out of the tombs of Corinth, Strab.

div1.head: νεκρόπολις
div1.sense: city of the dead, a suburb of Alexandria used as a burial place, Strab.

div1.head: νεκροπομπός
div1.sense: conducting the dead, of Charon, Eur., Luc.

div1.head: νεκρός
div1.sense: a dead body, corpse, Hom., etc.: —in pl. the dead, as dwellers in the nether world, Od.; τοὺς ἑαυτῶν ν. their own dead, of those killed in battle, Thuc.
as adj., νεκρός, ή, όν, dead, Pind.:— comp. -ότερος Anth.

div1.head: νεκροστολέω
div1.sense: to ferry the dead, of Charon, Luc.

div1.head: νεκροστόλος
div1.sense: a corpse-bearer,

div1.head: νεκροσυλία
div1.sense: robbery of the dead, Plat.

div1.head: νεκροφόνος
div1.sense: murderer of the dead, Anth.

div1.head: νεκροφόρος
div1.sense: burying the dead, Polyb.

div1.head: νεκρόω
div1.sense: to make dead:—Pass. to be dead, νεκρωθείς Anth.; νενεκρωμένος NTest.
to mortify, NTest.

div1.head: νεκρώδης
div1.sense: corpse-like, Luc.

div1.head: νεκρών
div1.sense: a burial-place, Anth.

div1.head: νέκρωσις
div1.sense: a state of death, deadness: death, NTest.

div1.head: νεκτάρεος
div1.sense: nectarous, of garments, prob., scented, fragrant, or generally, divine, beautiful, Il.:—literally, ν. σπονδαί libations of nectar, Pind.

div1.head: νέκταρ
div1.sense: nectar, the drink of the gods, as ambrosia was their food, Hom., etc.; poured like wine by Hebe, and mixed with water, Hom.
metaph., νέκταρ μελισσᾶν, i. e. honey, Eur.: of perfumed unguent, Anth.:—Pind. calls his Ode ν. χυτόν.

div1.head: νέκυια
div1.sense: a rite by which ghosts were called up and questioned, name for Od. II

div1.head: νεκυομαντεῖον
div1.sense: an oracle of the dead, a place where ghosts were called up and questioned, Hdt.

div1.head: νεκυοστόλος
div1.sense: ferrying the dead, of Charon, Anth.
bearing the dead, of a bier, Anth.

div1.head: νέκυς
div1.sense: a dead body, a corpse, corse, Hom., Hdt., Soph., etc.:— in pl. the spirits of the dead, Lat. Manes, inferi, in Od., Il.
as adj. dead, Soph., Anth.

div1.head: Νεμέα
div1.sense: Nemea, a wooded district between Argos and Corinth, Pind., etc.

div1.head: Νεμεάς
div1.sense: Nemean, Pind.
Νέμεα, poet. Νέμεια, (sc. ἱερά), τά, the Nemean games, celebrated in the second and fourth years of each Olympiad, Pind., Thuc.

div1.head: νεμέθω
div1.sense: Mid., νεμέθοντο the cattle were grazing, feeding, Il.

div1.head: Νέμειος
div1.sense: Nemean, Eur., etc.; also Νέμεος, Theocr.; Νεμειαῖος, Hes.; Νεμεαῖος, Pind.

div1.head: νεμεσάω
div1.sense: to feel just resentment, to be wroth at undeserved good or bad fortune (cf. νέμεσις) , properly of the gods, Il., Hes.; ν. τινι to be wroth with a person or at a thing, Hom.
Mid. and Pass., properly, to be displeased with oneself: to take shame to oneself, feel shame, Hom.
Mid. very much like the Act., c. dat. pers., Hom.; c. acc. et inf. to be indignant at seeing, Od.; c. acc. rei, νεμεσσᾶται κακὰ ἔργα visits evil deeds upon the doers, Od.

div1.head: νεμεσητικός
div1.sense: disposed to just indignation, Arist.

div1.head: νεμεσητός
div1.sense: causing indignation or wrath, νεμεσσητὸν δέ κεν εἴη ʼtwere enough to make one wroth, Il., etc.; so Soph., etc.
to be regarded with awe, awful, Il., Theocr.

div1.head: νεμεσίζομαι
div1.sense: Epic Dep. to be wroth with another, c. dat., Hom.; c. acc. rei, to be wroth with one for a thing, Il.; c. acc. et. inf. to be angry or amazed that . . , Il.
like νεμεσάομαι, to feel shame, c. acc. et inf., Il.
to dread, θεοὺς νεμεσίζετο he stood in awe of the gods, Od.

div1.head: νέμεσις
div1.sense: properly, distribution of what is due; hence a righteous assignment of anger, wrath at anything unjust, just resentment, Hom.: indignation at undeserved good fortune, Arist.
of the gods, indignation, wrath, ἐκ θεοῦ ν. Hdt., Soph.
the object of just resentment, Hom.; οὐ νέμεσις ἐστί ʼtis no cause for wrath that . . , c. inf., Hom., Soph.
indignation at oneʼs own misdeed, a sense of sin, Il.
Νέμεσις, ιος, as prop. n., voc. Νέμεσι, Nemesis, the impersonation of divine wrath, Hes.: in Trag., the goddess of retribution.

div1.head: νεμέτωρ
div1.sense: an avenger, Aesch.

div1.head: νέμος
div1.sense: a wooded pasture, glade, Lat. nemus, Il., Soph.

div1.head: νέμω
div1.sense: to deal out, distribute, dispense, of meat and drink, Hom., etc.; of the gods, νέμει ὄλβον Ὀλύμπιος ἀνθρώποισιν Od.; μοῖραν ν. τινί to pay one due respect, Aesch., etc.:—Pass., ἐπὶ τοὺς Ἕλληνας νέμεται is freely bestowed upon them, Hdt.; κρέα νενεμημένα portions of meat, Xen.
Mid. to distribute among themselves, and so, to have as oneʼs portion, possess, enjoy, Hom., etc.
to dwell in, inhabit, Hom.: absol. to dwell, Hdt.
to spend, pass, αἰῶνα, ἡμέραν Pind.
Act. much like Mid. to hold, possess, γῆν, χώραν, πόλιν Hdt., Attic:—Pass., of places, to be inhabited, Hdt.; of a country, to maintain itself, be constituted, Thuc.
to hold sway, manage, Hdt., Aesch.:— ν. οἴακα to manage the helm, Aesch.; ν. ἰσχὺν ἐπὶ σκήπτροισι to support oneʼs strength on staves, Aesch.; ν. γλῶσσαν to use the tongue, Aesch.
like νομίζω, to hold, consider as so and so, σὲ νέμω θεόν Soph.; προστάτην ν. τινά to take as oneʼs patron, Arist.
of herdsmen, to pasture or graze their flocks, drive to pasture, tend, Lat. pascere, Od., Hdt., Attic, etc.:—metaph., ν. χόλον Soph.

Mid., of cattle, to feed, i. e. go to pasture, graze, Lat. pasci, Hom., etc.: c. acc. cogn. to feed on, Hdt., etc.; of men, to eat, Soph.; of fire, to consume, devour, Il., etc.; of cancerous sores, to spread, ἐνέμετο πρόσω Hdt.
c. acc. loci, ὄρη νέμειν to graze the hills [with cattle], Xen.: Pass., [τὸ ὄρος νέμεται βουσί Xen.
metaph., πυρὶ νέμειν πόλιν to give a city to the flames, Hdt.: Pass., πυρὶ χθὼν νέμεται the land is devoured by fire, Il.

div1.head: νεοαρδής
div1.sense: newly watered, Il.

div1.head: νεόγαμος
div1.sense: newly married, a young husband or wife, Hdt.; ν. νύμφη, κόρη Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: νεογενής
div1.sense: new-born, Aesch., Plat.

div1.head: νεογιλός
div1.sense: new-born, young, Od., Theocr.

div1.head: νεογνός
div1.etym: contr. for νεόγονος, Hdt., Aesch., etc.

div1.head: νεόγραφος
div1.sense: newly painted or written, Anth.

div1.head: νεόγυιος
div1.sense: with young limbs, Pind.

div1.head: νεοδαμώδης
div1.sense: a Spartan word, newly enfranchised, Thuc.; Helots were called Νεοδαμώδεις when set free for service in war, Xen.

div1.head: νεόδαρτος
div1.sense: newly stripped off, Od.
newly flayed, βοῦς Xen.

div1.head: νεοδίδακτος
div1.sense: of dramas, newly brought out, Luc.

div1.head: νεοδμής
div1.sense: newly tamed, πῶλος Hhymn.; γάμοι a newly formed marriage, Eur.

div1.head: νεόδμητος
div1.sense: newly tamed, of horses: metaph. new-wedded, Eur.

div1.head: νεόδμητος2
div1.sense: new-built, Pind., Anth.

div1.head: νεόδρεπτος
div1.sense: fresh-plucked, βωμοὶ ν. altars wreathed with fresh-plucked leaves, Theocr.

div1.head: νεόδρομος
div1.sense: just having run, Babr.

div1.head: νεόζυγος
div1.sense: newly yoked: metaph. new-married, Eur.

div1.head: νεόθεν
div1.sense: newly, lately, Soph.

div1.head: νεοθηλής
div1.sense: fresh budding or sprouting, Il., Hes.
of animals, new-born, Anth.
metaph. fresh, εὐφροσύνη Hhymn.; ν. αὔξεται grows with youthful vigour, Pind.

div1.head: νεόθηλος
div1.sense: just giving milk, Aesch.

div1.head: νεοίη
div1.sense: youthful passion, Il.

div1.head: νέοικος
div1.sense: newly built, Pind.

div1.head: νεοκατάστατος
div1.sense: newly settled, Thuc.

div1.head: νεοκηδής
div1.sense: whose grief is fresh, freshgrieving, Hes.

div1.head: νεοκληρόνομος
div1.sense: having lately inherited, Anth.

div1.head: νεόκλωστος
div1.sense: fresh spun, Theocr.

div1.head: νεόκμητος
div1.sense: just slain, Eur.

div1.head: νεόκοπτος
div1.sense: fresh-chiselled, Ar.

div1.head: νεόκοτος
div1.sense: new and strange, unheard of, Aesch.
div1.etym: -κοτος seems to be a mere termin.

div1.head: νεοκράς
div1.sense: newly mixed: metaph. newly made, νεοκρᾶτα φίλον Aesch.

div1.head: νεόκτιστος
div1.sense: newly founded or built, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: νεόκτονος
div1.sense: lately or just killed, Pind.

div1.head: νεολαία
div1.sense: a band of youths, the youth of a nation, Lat. juventus, Aesch., Theocr.

div1.head: νεόλουτος
div1.sense: just bathed, Hhymn.

div1.head: νέομαι
div1.sense: to go or come (mostly with fut. sense), πάλιν ν. to go away or back, return, Hom.; οἶκόνδε νέεσθαι Hom.; of streams, to flow back, Il.

div1.head: νεοπενθής
div1.sense: fresh-mourning, Od.

div1.head: νεοπηγής
div1.sense: lately built or made, Anth.

div1.head: νεόπηκτος
div1.sense: fresh curdled, fresh made, Babr.

div1.head: νεόπλουτος
div1.sense: newly become rich, upstart (cf. Fr. nouveau riche), Dem., Arist.

div1.head: νεόπλυτος
div1.sense: newly washen, Od.

div1.head: νεόποκος
div1.sense: newly shorn, Soph.

div1.head: νεοπρεπής
div1.sense: befitting young people, youthful, extravagant, Plut.

div1.head: νεόπριστος
div1.sense: fresh-sawn, Od.

div1.head: Νεοπτόλεμος
div1.sense: surname of Pyrrhus, son of Achilles, new-warrior, because he came late to Troy, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: νεόπτολις
div1.sense: newly-founded, Aesch.

div1.head: νεόρραντος
div1.sense: fresh-reeking, Soph.

div1.head: νεόρρυτος
div1.sense: fresh-flowing, Soph., Anth.

div1.head: νεόρρυτος
div1.sense: newly drawn, Aesch.

div1.head: νέορτος
div1.sense: newly arisen, new, Soph.

div1.head: νεοσίγαλος
div1.sense: new and sparkling, with all the gloss on, Pind.

div1.head: νεοσκύλευτος
div1.sense: newly taken as booty, Anth.

div1.head: νεόσμηκτος
div1.sense: newly cleaned, Il., Plut.

div1.head: νεοσμίλευτος
div1.sense: new-carved, Anth.

div1.head: νεοσπαδής
div1.sense: newly drawn, Aesch.

div1.head: νεοσπάς
div1.sense: fresh-plucked, Soph.

div1.head: νέος
div1.sense: young, youthful, Hom.; or alone, νέοι youths, Il., Hes., etc.; in Attic with Art., ὁ νέος, οἱ νέοι, Ar., etc.:— τὸ νέον, νεότης, Soph.; ἐκ νέου from a youth, from youth upwards, Plat., etc.; ἐκ νέων Arist.
suited to a youth, youthful, Lat. juvenilis, Aesch., Eur.
of things, new, fresh, Il., Attic
of events, new, strange, τί νέον; Aesch.; μῶν τι βουλεύει νέον; Soph.

neut. νέον as adv. of Time, newly, lately, just, just now, Hom., Attic; also with the Art., καὶ τὸ παλαιὸν καὶ τὸ νέον Hdt.: comp. adv. νεωτέρως Plat.; Sup. νεώτατα most recently, Thuc.;—also, ἐκ νέας, Ionic ἐκ νέης, anew, afresh, Lat. denuo, Hdt.
for νεώτερος, νεώτατος, v. νεώτερος: the orig. comp. and Sup. were νεαρός, νέατος.

div1.head: νεόσπορος
div1.sense: newly sown, fresh-sown, Aesch.

div1.head: νεοσσεύω
div1.sense: to hatch, Ar.
to build a nest:—Pass., ὅσα ἦν νενεοσσευμένα ὀρνίθων γένεα as many as had their nests built, Hdt.

div1.head: νεοσσιά
div1.sense: a nest of young birds, a nest, Hdt., Attic

div0.div1: νεοσσίον Dim. of νεοσσός, νεοττός a young bird, nestling, chick, Ar.[accent varies: νεόσσιον, νεοσσίον]

div1.head: νεοσσοκόμος
div1.sense: rearing chickens, Anth.

div1.head: νεοσσός
div1.sense: a young bird, nestling, chick, Il., Soph., etc.
any young animal, as a young crocodile, Hdt.; of young children, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: νεοσσοτροφέω
div1.sense: Pass. to be reared as in the nest, of a child, Ar.

div1.head: νεόστροφος
div1.sense: newly twisted, νευρή Il.

div1.head: νεοσφαγής
div1.sense: fresh-slain, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: νεοτελής
div1.sense: newly initiated, Plat.

div1.head: νεότευκτος
div1.sense: newly wrought, Il.

div1.head: νεοτευχής
div1.sense: newly made, Il.

div1.head: νεότης
div1.sense: youth, Lat. juventa, Il., Eur., etc.
youthful spirit, impetuosity, Hdt.: in bad sense, rashness, petulance, Plat., etc.
collective, like νεολαία, a body of youth, the youth, Lat. juventus, Hdt., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: νεότμητος
div1.sense: newly cut, Theocr.

div1.head: νεοτόκος
div1.sense: having just brought forth, Eur.

div1.head: νεότομος
div1.sense: fresh cut or ploughed, Aesch.; ν. πλήγματα newly inflicted, Soph.
fresh cut off, fresh cut, ἕλιξ Eur.

div1.head: νεουργέω
div1.sense: to make new, renew, Anth.

div1.head: νεουργός
div1.sense: new-made, Plat., Plut.

div1.head: νεούτατος
div1.sense: lately wounded, Il., Hes.

div1.head: νεόφοιτος
div1.sense: newly trodden, Anth.

div1.head: νεόφονος
div1.sense: of blood, fresh-shed, Eur.

div1.head: νεόφυτος
div1.sense: newly planted: metaph. a new convert, neophyte, NTest.

div1.head: νεοχάρακτος
div1.sense: newly imprinted, Soph.

div1.head: νεοχμός
div1.sense: new, Aesch., Eur., Ar.
of political innovations, νεοχμόν τι ποιέειν, νεοχμόω, Hdt.

div1.head: νεοχμόω
div1.sense: to make political innovations, Lat. res novas tentare, πολλὰ νεόχμωσε caused many innovations, Thuc.

div1.head: νεόχνοoς
div1.sense: with the first down or beard, Anth.

div1.head: νεόω
div1.sense: to renovate, renew, νέωσον Aesch.:—Mid., τάφους ἐνεώσατο had them renewed, Anth.

div1.head: νέπους
div1.sense: pl. νέποδεςyoung ones, children, Od., Theocr.
div1.etym: An old word of uncertain deriv.

div1.head: νερτέριος
div1.sense: underground, anth.

div1.head: νερτεροδρόμος
div1.sense: the courier of the dead, Luc.

div1.head: νέρτερος
div1.sense: lower, nether, Lat. inferior, a comp. without any Posit. in use (νέρθε, ἔνερθε) , Aesch.
mostly of the world below, Trag.; ἡ νερτέρα θεός Soph.; νέρτεροι, Lat. inferi, the dead, Aesch., etc.; also, ν. πλάκες, χθών, δώματα, of the realms below, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: νέρτος
div1.sense: an unknown bird of prey, Ar.

div1.head: νεῦμα
div1.sense: a nod or sign, Thuc.; νεύματος ἕνεκα for a mere nod, i. e. without cause, Xen.

div1.head: νευρά
div1.sense: a string or cord of sinew, a bowstring, Hom., Hes., etc.

div1.head: νευρολάλος
div1.sense: with sounding strings, Anth.

div1.head: νεῦρον
div1.sense: a sinew, tendon; in pl., the tendons of the feet, Il., Plat.
metaph. in pl., τὰ νεῦρα τῆς τραγῳδίας, of lyric odes, their sinews, vigour, Ar.; τὰ νεῦρα τῶν πραγμάτων Aeschin.
gut, cord made of sinew, for fastening the head of the arrow to the shaft, Il.: the cord of a sling, Xen.

div1.head: νευροπλεκής
div1.sense: plaited with sinews, Anth.

div1.head: νευρορραφέω
div1.sense: to stitch or mend shoes, Xen.

div1.head: νευρορράφος
div1.sense: one who stitches with sinews, a mender of shoes, cobbler, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: νευροσπαδής
div1.sense: drawn by the string, ν. ἄτρακτος the arrow drawn and just ready to fly, Soph.

div1.head: νευρόσπαστος
div1.sense: drawn by strings, moved by strings, of puppets, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: νευροτενής
div1.sense: stretched by sinews, made of gut, Anth.

div1.head: νευροχαρής
div1.sense: delighting in the bowstring or in the lyre, Anth.

div1.head: νευστάζω
div1.sense: to nod, of a warrior threatening his foe, Il.; of one making signs, Od.; of one fainting, Od.

div1.head: νευστέος
div1.sense: one must swim, Plat.

div1.head: νευστικός
div1.sense: able to swim, Plat.

div1.head: νεύω
div1.sense: to nod or beckon, as a sign, Hom.: c. inf. to beckon to one to do a thing, in token of command, Hom., Eur.
to nod or bow in token of assent, Hom., Soph.:—c. acc. et inf. to promise that, Il.:—c. acc. rei, to grant, promise, Soph., Eur.
generally, to bow the head, bend forward, of warriors charging, Il.; of ears of corn, Hes.; ν. κάτω to stoop, Eur.:—c. acc. cogn., ν. κεφαλήν Od.
to incline in any way, ν. εἴς τι to incline towards, Thuc.:—of countries, like Lat. vergere, to slope, ν. εἰς δύσιν Polyb.

div1.head: νεφεληγερέτα
div1.etym: only in nom. and in Epic gen. νεφεληγερέταο
div1.sense: cloud-gatherer, cloud-compeller, of Zeus, Hom.

div1.head: νεφέλη
div1.sense: a cloud, Hom., etc.
metaph., νεφέλη δέ μιν ἀμφεκάλυψεν κυανέη, of death, Il.; ἄχεος ν. a cloud of sorrow, Hom.; Κενταύρου φονίᾳ νεφέλᾳ, i. e. with his blood, Soph.
a bird-net, Ar.

div1.head: Νεφελοκένταυρος
div1.sense: a cloud-centaur, Luc.

div1.head: Νεφελοκοκκυγία
div1.sense: Cloud-cuckoo-town, built by the birds in Ar.

div1.head: Νεφελοκοκκυγιεύς
div1.sense: a Cloud-cuckoo-man, Ar.

div1.head: νεφελωτός
div1.etym: as if from νεφελόω to form clouds
div1.sense: clouded, made of clouds, Luc.

div1.head: νεφοειδής
div1.sense: cloud-like, Anth.

div1.head: νέφος
div1.sense: a cloud, mass or pile of clouds, Hom., etc.
metaph., θανάτου νέφος the cloud of death, Hom.; so, σκότου ν., of blindness, Soph.; ν. οἰμωγῆς, στεναγμῶν Eur.; ν. ὀφρύων a cloud upon the brows, Eur.
metaph. also a cloud of men or birds, Il., Hdt.; ν. πολέμοιο the cloud of battle, Il.

div1.head: νεφρῖτις
div1.sense: νεφρῖτις ( sc. νόσος) nephritis, a disease of the kidneys, Thuc.

div1.head: νεφρός
div1.sense: in pl. the kidneys, Plat., etc.; so in dual, Ar.

div1.head: νέω
div1.sense: to swim, Od., Hdt., etc.:— metaph. of shoes that are too large, ἔνεον ἐν ταῖς ἐμβάσιν I was floating in my shoes, as if they were boats, Ar.

div1.head: νέω
div1.sense: to spin, of a spider, νεῖ νήματα Hes.: Mid., ἅσσα οἱ νήσαντο the threads which [the Fates] spun out to him, Od.:—Pass., τὰ νηθέντα Plat.

div1.head: νέω
div1.sense: to heap, pile, heap up, πυρὰν νῆσαι to pile a funeral pyre, Hdt.; νήσαντες ξύλα Eur.:—Pass., ἀμφορῆς νενησμένοι Ar.; ἄρτοι νενημένοι Xen.

div1.head: νεωκορέω
div1.sense: to serve a temple: ironically, to sweep clean, clean out, plunder a temple, Plat.

div1.head: νεωκορία
div1.sense: the office of a νεωκόρος, Anth.

div1.head: νεωκόρος
div1.sense: the custodian of a temple, Lat. aedituus, Plat., Xen.
a title of Asiatic towns, which had built a temple in honour of their patron-god, as Ephesus was, ν. Ἀρτέμιδος NTest.

div1.head: νεωλκέω
div1.sense: to haul a ship up on land, Lat. subducere navem, Polyb.

div1.head: νεωλκός
div1.sense: a ship-hauler, Arist.

div1.head: νεώνητος
div1.sense: newly bought, of slaves, Ar.

div1.head: νεώρης
div1.sense: new, fresh, late, Lat. recens, νεώρη βόστρυχον τετμημένον a lock of hair but just cut off, Soph.; φόβος νεώρης Soph.

div1.head: νεώριον
div1.sense: a place were ships are taken care of, a dockyard, Ar., Thuc.; also in pl., like Lat. navalia, Eur., Thuc., etc. Cf. νεώσοικος.

div1.head: νεώσοικος
div1.sense: a dock, Ar.:—in pl. sheds, slips, docks, in which ships might be built, repaired, or laid up, being parts of the νεώριον, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: νεώς
div1.etym: Attic for ναός, as λεώς for λαός
div1.sense: a temple, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: νεωστί
div1.etym: adverb of νέος, for νέως, as μεγαλωστί for μεγάλως
div1.sense: lately, just now, Hdt., Soph.

div1.head: νέωτα
div1.sense: adv. next year, for next year, εἰς νέωτα Xen., Theocr.

div1.head: νεώτατος
div1.sense: youngest, Il.
most recent, Arist.

div1.head: νεωτερίζω
div1.sense: to attempt anything new, make a violent change, Thuc., Xen., etc.: ν. ἐς τὴν ἀσθένειαν to change [health] into sickness, Thuc.
to attempt political changes, make innovations or revolutionary movements, Lat. res novas tentare, Thuc., etc.
c. acc., ν. τὴν πολιτείαν to revolutionise the state, Thuc.:—Pass., ἐνεωτερίζετο τὰ περὶ τὴν ὀλιγαρχίαν Thuc.

div1.head: νεωτερισμός
div1.sense: innovation, revolutionary movement, Plat., etc.

div1.head: νεωτεριστής
div1.sense: an innovator, Plut.

div1.head: νεωτεροποιία
div1.sense: innovation, revolution, Thuc.

div1.head: νεωτεροποιός
div1.sense: innovating, revolutionary, Thuc. Arist.

div1.head: νεώτερος
div1.sense: younger, Il., Soph.:— οἱ νεώτεροι the younger sort, men of military age, Thuc.
too young, Od.:—c. gen., οἱ νεώτεροι τῶν πραγμάτων those who are too young to remember the events, Dem.
of events, newer, later, Pind.: metaph. later, worse, Soph.; νεώτερα alone, Lat. gravius quid, Hdt., Attic; μῶν τι ν. ἀγγέλλεις; Plat.; νεώτερα βουλεύειν or ποιεῖν περί τινος Hdt., Thuc.
of political changes, νεώτερόν τι, an innovation, revolutionary movement, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: νηγάτεος
div1.sense: new-made, Il.

div1.head: νήγρετος
div1.sense: unwaking, νήγρετος ὕπνος a sleep that knows no waking, deep sleep, Od.; neut. as adv., νήγρετον εὕδειν without waking, Od.

div1.head: νήδυια
div1.sense: the bowels, entrails, Il.

div1.head: νήδυμος
div1.sense: epith. of ὕπνος, either = ἡδύς, sweet, delightful; or
from νη-, δύνω, sleep from which one rises not, sound sleep, much like νήγρετος, Hom.

div1.head: νηδύς
div1.sense: the stomach, Od., Hes., Aesch., etc.
the belly, paunch, Il., Hdt.; the womb, Il.: metaph., of earth, gremium telluris, Eur.

div1.head: νηέω
div1.sense: Epic longer form of νέω D: Epic aor1 νήησα:— to heap, heap or pile up, Hom.
to pile, load, νῆας νηήσας εὖ Il.: Mid., νῆα χρυσοῦ νηησάσθω let him pile his ship with gold, Il.

div1.head: νήθω
div1.sense: to spin, Plat.; 2nd sg. Ionic imperf. νήθεσκες, Anth.

div1.head: νήϊος
div1.sense: of or for a ship, δόρυ νήιον or νήιον alone, ship-timber, Hom.

div1.head: νῆϊς
div1.sense: unknowing of, unpractised in a thing, c. gen., Od.; absol., Il.

div1.head: νηΐτης
div1.sense: consisting of ships, στρατὸς ν. a fleet, Thuc.

div1.head: νηκερδής
div1.sense: unprofitable, Hom.

div1.head: νήκερως
div1.sense: not horned, Epic nom. pl. νήκεροι Hes.

div1.head: νήκεστος
div1.sense: incurable, neut. as adv. incurably, Hes.

div1.head: νηκουστέω
div1.sense: not to hear, to give no heed to, disobey one, c. gen., Il.

div1.head: νηκτός
div1.sense: swimming, Anth.

div1.head: νηλεόποινος
div1.sense: punishing without pity, ruthlessly punishing, Hes.

div1.head: Νηλεύς
div1.sense: father of Nestor, Hom.:—Epic adj. Νηλήιος, Il., etc.:—Patr., Νηλείδης, ου, ὁ, and Νηληιάδης, εω, or ᾱο, Hom.

div1.head: νηλής
div1.sense: pitiless, ruthless, Il.; νηλέϊ χαλκῷ with ruthless steel, Hom.; νηλέϊ ὕπνῳ relentless sleep, which exposes men without defence to ill, Od.; νηλεὲς ἦμαρ, i. e. the day of death, Hom.:— adv. νηλεῶς Aesch.
pass. unpitied, Soph.

div1.head: νηλιποκαιβλεπέλαιοι
div1.sense: nickname of philosophers, barefoot and looking after oil, Anth.

div1.head: νηλίπους
div1.sense: unshod, barefooted, Soph.
div1.etym: Commonly deriv. from νη-, ἦλιψ without shoe.

div1.head: νηλεῖτις
div1.sense: guiltless, harmless, Od.

div1.head: νῆμα
div1.sense: that which is spun, a thread, yarn, Od., Hes., Eur.

div1.head: νημέρτεια
div1.sense: certainty, truth, Doric νᾱμέρτεια, Soph.

div1.head: νημερτής
div1.sense: unerring, infallible, Od., Hes.; νημερτέα βουλήν a sure decree, i. e. one that will infallibly be enforced, Od.; νημερτέα εἰπεῖν or μυθήσασθαι to speak sure truths, Hom.; Ionic adv. νημερτέως as trisyll., Od.

div1.head: νηνεμία
div1.sense: stillness in the air, a calm, νηνεμίης in a calm, Il.; γαλήνη ἔπλετο νηνεμίη there was a calm, a ceasing of all winds, Od.; ἐξ αἰθρίης τε καὶ νηνεμίης Hdt.

div1.head: νήνεμος
div1.sense: without wind, breezeless, calm, hushed, Il., Aesch., Eur.:—metaph., ν. ἔστησʼ ὄχλον Eur.

div1.head: νῆξις
div1.sense: a swimming, Batr.

div1.head: νηοπόλος
div1.sense: busying oneself in a temple: a temple-keeper, Hes., Anth.

div1.head: νηοπορέω
div1.sense: to go by sea, Anth.

div1.head: νηοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing ships, Anth.

div1.head: νή
div1.sense: Attic Particle of strong affirmation, like Epic ναί; with acc. of the Divinity invoked, νὴ Δία (in familiar Attic, νὴ Δί or νηδί) , Ar.; also with the Art., νὴ τὸν Δία Ar.; νὴ τὴν Ἀθηνᾶν, νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν, νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ Ar.

div1.head: νη-
div1.sense: negat. Prefix, being a stronger form of ἀνα- privat., combined with short vowels, as in νηλεής, νήριθμος, νήκεστος, νήνεμος, or before consonants, as in νηκερδής, νηπενθής, νήποινος.

div1.head: νηπενθής
div1.sense: banishing pain, φάρμακον νηπενθές an opiate, Od.:— νηπενθής, as epith. of Apollo, Anth.

div1.head: νηπιάα
div1.sense: childhood, ἐν νηπιέῃ Il.:—in pl. childish tricks or follies, νηπιέῃσιν in childish fashion, in folly, Hom.

div1.head: νηπιαχεύω
div1.sense: to be childish, play like a child, Il.

div1.head: νηπίαχος
div1.sense: Epic Dim. of νήπιος, infantine, childish, Il.

div1.head: νήπιος
div1.sense: not yet speaking, Lat. infans, Hom.; νήπια τέκνα, βρέφος ν. Eur.:—also νήπια young animals, Il.
metaph. like a child, childish, silly, Hom., Hes.; without forethought, Hom., Aesch.

div1.head: νηπιότης
div1.sense: childhood, childishness, Plat.

div1.head: νηπιόφρων
div1.sense: of childish mind, silly, Strab.

div1.head: νήπλεκτος
div1.sense: with unbraided hair, Bion.

div1.head: νηποινεί
div1.sense: Lat. impune, Plat.

div1.head: νήποινος
div1.sense: unavenged, Hom.:—neut. νήποινον as adv., Od.
φυτῶν νήποινος without share of fruitful trees, Pind.

div1.head: νηπυτιεύομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to play childʼs tricks, Anth.

div1.head: νηπύτιος
div1.sense: a little child, Il., Ar.
as adj. like a child, childish, Il.

div1.head: Νηρεύς
div1.sense: Nereus, a sea-god, son of Πόντος (the sea), father of the Nereids, Hes.

div1.head: Νηρηΐς
div1.sense: a daughter of Nereus, a Nereid or Nymph of the sea, mostly in pl., Νηρηίδες, Hom.; Νηρεΐδες Hes.; Attic Νηρῇδες Soph., Eur.

div1.head: νήριθμος
div1.sense: countless, Theocr.

div1.head: νήριτος
div1.sense: countless, immense, Hes.:— hence the name of the Ithacan mountain, Νήριτον εἰνοσίφυλλον Hom.

div1.head: νησαῖος
div1.sense: of an island, insular, Eur.

div1.head: νησίδιον
div1.sense: an islet, Thuc.

div1.head: νησίζω
div1.sense: to be or form an island, Polyb.

div1.head: νησίον
div1.sense: an islet, Strab.

div1.head: νῆσις
div1.sense: spinning, Plat.

div1.head: νησίς
div1.sense: an islet, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: νησίτης
div1.sense: of or belonging to an island: Doric fem. νᾱσῖτις, ιδος, Anth.

div1.head: νησιώτης
div1.sense: an islander, Hdt., Ar., etc.
as adj. of or in an island, insular , Hdt., Eur.; νησιῶτις πέτρα an island rock, Aesch.

div1.head: νησιωτικός
div1.sense: of or from an island, Hdt., Eur.; ὄνομα νησιωτικὸν Σαλαμῖνα θέμενον having given it the island name of Salamis, Eur.:— τὸ ν. insular situation, Thuc.

div1.head: νησοειδής
div1.sense: like an island, Strab.

div1.head: νησομαχία
div1.sense: an island-fight, Luc.

div1.head: νῆσος
div1.sense: an island, Lat. insula, Hom., Hes., etc.; ἐν τᾷ μεγάλᾳ Δωρίδι νάσῳ Πέλοπος, i. e. in Peloponnese, Soph.; μακάρων νῆσοι, v. sub μάκαρ.
div1.etym: Perhaps from νέω to swim, as if floating land.

div1.head: νηστεία
div1.sense: a fast, Hdt.

div1.head: νηστεύω
div1.sense: to fast, Ar.

div1.head: νῆστις
div1.sense: not eating, fasting, of persons, Hom.; c. gen., νῆστις βορᾶς Eur.:—metaph., νῆστιν ἀνὰ ψάμμον over the hungry sand, Aesch.
νῆστις νόσος, λιμός hungry famine, Aesch.; νήστισιν αἰκίαις the pains of hunger, Aesch.; νήστιδες δύαι Aesch.
act. causing hunger, starving, πνοιαὶ νήστιδες Aesch.

div1.head: νήτιτος
div1.sense: unavenged, Anth.

div1.head: νητός
div1.sense: heaped, piled up, Od.

div1.head: νῆττα
div1.sense: a duck, Lat. anas (gen. a-nat-is), Hdt., Ar., etc.

div1.head: νηττάριον
div1.sense: a little duck, Ar.

div1.head: νήϋτμος
div1.sense: breathless, Hes.

div1.head: νηφάλιος
div1.sense: unmixed with wine, wineless, νηφ. μειλίγματα the offerings to the Eumenides, composed of water, milk, and honey, Aesch.
of persons, sober, NTest.

div1.head: νήφων
div1.sense: sober, Theogn., Soph.

div1.head: νήφω
div1.sense: to drink no wine, Theogn., Plat.; part. νήφων as adj. = νηφάλιος, Hdt., Plat.
metaph. to be sober, dispassionate, Xen.

div1.head: νήχω
div1.sense: to swim, Act. Od., Hes. also as Dep., Od., Anth.

div1.head: νῆψις
div1.sense: soberness, Strab.

div1.head: νίγλαρος
div1.sense: a pipe or whistle, used by the κελευστής to give the time in rowing, Ar.

div1.head: νίζω
div1.etym: the pres. νίπτω, from which the tenses are formed, only in late writers
div1.sense: to wash the hands or feet of another, Od.:—Mid., χεῖρας νίψασθαι to wash oneʼs hands, Il., Hes.; so, νίψασθαι, absol., to wash oneʼs hands, Od., etc.; νίψασθαι ἁλός to wash [with water] from the sea, Od.
generally to purge, cleanse, Soph., Eur.

to wash off, ἱδρῶ νίψεν ἀπὸ χρωτός washed off the sweat from the skin, Il.; αἷμα νίζʼ ὕδατι Il.:—Mid., χρόα νίζετο ἅλμην he washed the brine off his skin, Od.:—Pass., αἷμα νένιπται Il.—The word is commonly said of persons washing part of the person, while λούομαι is used of bathing, πλύνω of washing clothes.

div1.head: νικάτωρ
div1.sense: a conqueror, Plut.

div1.head: νικάω
div1.sense: absol. to conquer, prevail, vanquish, Hom., etc.; ὁ νικήσας the conqueror, ὁ νικηθείς the conquered, Il.; ἐνίκησα καὶ δεύτερος καὶ τέταρτος ἐγενόμην I won the first prize, Thuc.; νικᾶν ἐπὶ πᾶσι κριταῖς in the opinion of all the judges, Ar.; c. acc. cogn., πάντα ἐνίκα he won all the bouts, Il.; παγκράτιον Thuc.; ν. Ὀλύμπια to be conqueror in the Ol. games, Thuc., etc.

of opinions, to prevail, carry the day, Hom., etc.; ἐκ τῆς νικώσης γνώμης according to the prevailing opinion, vote of the majority, Xen.:—impers., ἐνίκα (sc. ἡ γνώμη) it was resolved, Lat. visum est, c. inf., ἐνίκα μὴ ἐκλιπεῖν τὴν πόλιν it was carried not to leave the city, Hdt.; ἐνίκησε λοιμὸν εἰρῆσθαι it was the general opinion that λοιμός was the word, Thuc.
as law-term, ν. τὴν δίκην to win oneʼs cause, Eur., Ar.
c. acc. pers. to conquer, vanquish, Hom., etc.; μὴ φῦναι τὸν ἅπαντα νικᾶι λόγον not to be born is best, Soph.; νίκης νικᾶν τινα to win victory over one, Od.

generally of passions, etc., to conquer, to overpower, Il.; βαρεῖαν ἡδονὴν νικᾶτέ με ye force me to grant you pleasure against my will, Soph.; c. inf., μηδʼ ἡ βία σε νικησάτω μισεῖν let not force prevail on thee to hate, Soph.
Pass., νικᾶσθαί τινος, like ἡττᾶσθαι, to be inferior to, give way, yield to, Soph., Eur.; ἢν τοῦτο νικηθῆις ἐμοῦ Ar.

div1.head: νικήεις
div1.sense: victorious, Anth.

div1.head: νίκημα
div1.sense: victory, Polyb.

div1.head: νίκη
div1.sense: victory in battle, Il., etc.; in the games, Pind., etc.:—c. gen. subjecti, νίκη φαίνεται Μενελάου plainly belongs to Menelaus, Il.; but c. gen. objecti, νίκη ἀντιπάλων victory over opponents, Ar.
generally, the upper hand, ascendancy, νίκην διασώζεσθαι to keep the fruits of victory, Xen.
as prop. n. Nike, the goddess of victory, Hes.

div1.head: νικητέος
div1.sense: one must conquer, Eur.

div1.head: νικητήριος
div1.sense: belonging to a conqueror or to victory; ν. φίλημα a kiss as the conquerorʼs reward, Xen.
as Subst., νικητήριον (sc. ἆθλον) , the prize of victory, Ar., Xen.; mostly in pl., Eur., Plat.
νικητήρια (sc. ἱερά), τά, the festival of victory, Xen.

div1.head: νικητικός
div1.sense: likely to conquer, conducing to victory, Xen.; τὸ νικητικώτατον the most likely way to conquer, Plut.

div1.head: νικηφορέω
div1.sense: to carry off as a prize, δάκρυα ν. to win naught but tears, Eur.

div1.head: νικηφορία
div1.sense: a conquering, victory, Pind.

div1.head: νικηφόρος
div1.sense: bringing victory, Aesch.
(φέρομαι) bearing off the prize, conquering, victorious, Pind., Soph., etc.

div1.head: νικόβουλος
div1.sense: prevailing in the council, Ar.

div1.head: νιν
div1.sense: Doric and Trag. enclit. acc. of 3rd pers. Pron., like Epic and Ionic μιν, for αὐτόν, αὐτήν, him, her, Pind., Trag.;—rarely for αὐτό, it, Pind., Aesch.; and for αὐτούς, -τάς (in pl.), Pind.
for dat. αὐτῷ, Pind.

div1.head: νιπτήρ
div1.sense: a washing vessel, basin, NTest.

div1.head: νίπτρον
div1.sense: water for washing, mostly in pl., Eur., Anth.

div1.head: νίσσομαι
div1.sense: like νέομαι to go, go away, Hom., Pind.; c. acc. loci, to go to a place, Eur.

div1.head: νίτρον
div1.sense: in Hdt. and Attic λίτρον, carbonate of soda, Hdt.

div1.head: νίφα
div1.sense: snow, acc. formed from a nom. νίψ, which is not found, Hes.

div1.head: νιφάς
div1.sense: a snowflake, in pl. snowflakes, Il., Hdt.; as a simile for persuasive eloquence, ἔπεα νιφάδεσσι ἐοικότα χειμερίῃσιν Il.:—the sg. in collective sense, a snowstorm, snow, Il., Pind.
generally, a shower of stones, Aesch., Eur.; ν. πολέμου the sleet of war, Pind.
as fem. adj., = νιφόεσσα, Soph.

div1.head: νιφετός
div1.sense: falling snow, a snowstorm, Hom., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: νιφετώδης
div1.sense: like snow, snowy, Polyb.

div1.head: νιφόβολος
div1.sense: snow-stricken, snowclad, of mountains, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: νιφόεις
div1.sense: snowy, snowclad, snowcapt, Hom., Hes., etc.

div1.head: νιφοστιβής
div1.sense: piled with snow, Soph.

div1.head: νίφω
div1.sense: to snow, pers., ὅτε ὤρετο Ζεὺς νιφέμεν (Epic inf.) when Zeus started to snow, Il.; ὅταν νίφηι ὁ θεός Xen.:—metaph., χρυσῶι νίφων falling in a shower of gold, Pind.
impers., νίφει it snows (cf. ὕω, συσκοτάζω), Ar.:—so in Mid., νιφάδος νιφομένας when the snow is snowing, Aesch.
Pass. to be snowed on, Hdt., Ar., etc.

div1.head: νοερός
div1.sense: intellectual, Plat., etc.

div1.head: νοέω
div1.sense: to perceive by the eyes, observe, notice, ὀφθαλμοῖς or ἐν ὀφθαλμοῖς νοέειν Il.; distinguished from mere sight, τὸν δὲ ἰδὼν ἐνόησε Il.; οὐκ ἴδεν οὐδʼ ἐνόησε Hom.:—hence, θυμῶι νοέω καὶ οἶδα ἕκαστα Od., etc.: —so in Mid., Theogn., Soph.
absol. to think, suppose, Hom., Hdt., etc.; ἄλλα ν. to be of another mind, Hdt.:—part. νοέων, έουσα thoughtful, wary, discreet, Hom.
to think out, devise, contrive, purpose, intend, Od., Hdt.
c. inf. to be minded to do a thing, Il., Soph., etc.:—so in Mid., Il., Hdt.
to conceive of or deem to be so and so, ὡς μηκέτʼ ὄντα κεῖνον νόει Soph.
of words, to bear a certain sense, to mean so and so, πυθοίμεθʼ ἂν τὸν χρησμὸν ὅ τι νοεῖ Ar., Plat.

div1.head: νόημα
div1.sense: that which is perceived, a perception, thought, Hom., Hes., Attic: as an emblem of swiftness, ὡσεὶ πτερὸν ἠὲ νόημα Od.
a thought, purpose, design, Hom., Ar.
like νόησις, understanding, mind, Hom.: disposition, Pind.

div1.head: νοήμων
div1.sense: thoughtful, intelligent, Od.
in oneʼs right mind, Hdt.

div1.head: νόησις
div1.sense: intelligence, thought, Plat.

div1.head: νοητικός
div1.sense: intelligent, Arist.

div1.head: νοητός
div1.sense: perceptible to the mind, thinkable, opp. to visible (ὁρατός) , Plat.

div1.head: νοθαγενής
div1.sense: base-born, Eur.

div1.head: νοθεία
div1.sense: birth out of wedlock, Plut.

div1.head: νοθεύω
div1.sense: to adulterate: Pass., aor1 inf. νοθευθῆναι Luc.

div1.head: νοθοκαλλοσύνη
div1.sense: counterfeit charms, Anth.

div1.head: νόθος
div1.sense: a bastard, baseborn child, i. e. one born of a slave or concubine, opp. to γνήσιος, Lat. legitimus, Il., Hdt., Attic; νόθη κούρη Il.
generally, spurious, counterfeit, supposititious, Plat.

div1.head: νομαδικός
div1.sense: of or for a herdsmanʼs life, nomadic, pastoral, Arist.:—adv. -κῶς, like Nomads, Strab.
Numidian, Polyb.

div1.head: νόμαιος
div1.sense: customary: νόμαια, ων, τά, like νόμιμα, customs, usages, Hdt.

div1.head: νομάρχης
div1.sense: the chief of an Egyptian province (νομός) , Hdt.

div1.head: νομάς
div1.sense: roaming about for pasture: οἱ Νομάδες roaming, pastoral tribes, Nomads, Hdt., Attic; and as prop. n., Numidians, Polyb.
fem. adj. grazing, feeding, at pasture, Soph.
metaph., κρῆναι νομάδες wandering streams, Soph.

div1.head: νόμευμα
div1.sense: that which is put to graze, i. e. a flock, Aesch.

div1.head: νομεύς
div1.sense: a shepherd, herdsman, Hom., etc.
a dealer out, distributer, ἀγαθῶν Plat.
pl. νομέες, the ribs of a ship, Hdt.

div1.head: νομεύω
div1.sense: to put to graze, drive afield, of the shepherd, Od.:—in Pass. of the flocks, to go to pasture, Plat.
βουσὶ νομοὺς ν. to eat down the pastures with oxen, Lat. depascere, Hhymn.
absol. to be a shepherd, tend flocks, Theocr.

div1.head: νομή
div1.sense: a pasture, pasturage, Hdt., Soph.
fodder, food, Plat.
a feeding, grazing, of herds: metaph., νομὴ πυρός a spreading of fire, Polyb.; νομὴν ἔχειν, of a cancerous sore, to spread, NTest.
division, distribution, Hdt., Plat., etc.

div1.head: νομίζω
div1.sense: to hold or own as a custom or usage, to use customarily, practise, Hdt.; ν. γλῶσσαν to have a language in common use, Hdt.; ν. οὔτε ἀσπίδα οὔτε δόρυ Hdt.:—Pass. to be the custom, be customary, Aesch.; σωφροσύνη νενόμιστο was the fashion, Ar.; —impers., ὡς νομίζεται as is the custom, Trag.:—part. νομιζόμενος, η, ον, customary, usual, Thuc.; τὰ νομιζόμενα customs, usages, Lat. instituta, Hdt., Attic; τὰ νομισθέντα Eur.
to adopt a custom or usage, Ἕλληνες ἀπʼ Αἰγυπτίων ταῦτα νενομίκασι Hdt.
c. dat. to be used to a thing, νομίζουσιν Αἰγύπτιοι οὐδʼ ἥρωσιν οὐδέν, i. e. do not worship heroes, Hdt.: hence to make common use of, use, φωνῆι Hdt.; ἀγῶσι καὶ θυσίαις Thuc.

c. inf. to have a custom of doing, to be accustomed to do, Hdt.:—Pass. impers., γυμνοὺς εἰσιέναι νομίζεται it is customary for them . . , Ar.; νενόμισται καλέεσθαι it has been usual to be called, Hdt.
Pass. to be ordered and governed after old laws and customs, Hdt.

to own, acknowledge, consider as, τοὺς κακοὺς χρηστοὺς ν. Soph.; νομίσαι χρὴ ταῦτα μυστήρια Ar.:— θεὸν ν. τινά to hold or believe in one as a god, Plat., Xen.:—hence, νομίζειν τούτους θεούς to believe in these [as gods], Hdt.; οὓς ἡ πόλις νομίζει θεοὺς οὐ νομίζων not believing in the gods in which the State believes, Xen., Plat.: —but, νομίζειν θεοὺς εἶναι to believe that there are gods, Plat.; θεοὺς ν. οὐδαμοῦ Aesch.;—so that ν. τοὺς θεούς and ν. θεούς differ, the one being to believe in certain gods, the other to believe in gods generally, cf. ἡγέομαι III. 2 :—Pass., Ἕλληνες ἤρξαντο νομισθῆναι to be considered as . . , Hdt.
to esteem or hold in honour, Pind.:—Pass. to be in esteem, Plat.
c. acc. rei, to deem, hold, believe, τι περί τινος Plat.
c. acc. et inf. to deem, hold, believe that, Soph., Xen.;—also, like δοκέω, c. inf. fut. to expect that . . , Soph.
Pass., with gen. of the person in possession, τοῦ θεῶν νομίζεται; whose sanctuary is it held to be? Soph.
absol., νομίζοντα λέγειν to speak with full belief, Plat.

div1.head: νομικός
div1.sense: resting on law, conventional, Arist.:—adv. -κῶς, Arist.
relating to the law, NTest. Plut.
learned in the law, a lawyer, NTest.

div1.head: νόμιμος
div1.sense: conformable to custom, usage, or law, customary, prescriptive, established, lawful, rightful, Eur.:— νόμιμόν ἐστί τινι ποιεῖν τι Xen.
νόμιμα, ων, τά, usages, customs, Hdt., Attic
funeral rites, Lat. justa, Thuc.
adv. -μως, Plat.: comp. -ώτερον Xen.

div1.head: νόμιος
div1.sense: of shepherds, pastoral, ν. θεός, i. e. Pan, Hhymn.; of Apollo, as shepherd of Admetus, Theocr.

div1.head: νόμισις
div1.sense: usage, prescription, custom, ἡ ἁνθρωπεία ἐς τὸ θεῖον νόμισις the established belief about the Deity, Thuc.

div1.head: νόμισμα
div1.sense: anything sanctioned by usage, a custom, institution, Trag., Ar.
the current coin of a state, Hdt.

div1.head: νομιστέος
div1.sense: to be accounted, Plat.

div1.head: νομιστεύομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be current, Polyb.

div1.head: νομογραφία
div1.sense: written legislation, Strab.

div1.head: νομογράφος
div1.sense: (νόμος II) a composer of music, Plat.

div1.head: νομοδείκτης
div1.sense: one who explains laws, Plut.

div1.head: νομοδιδάσκαλος
div1.sense: a teacher of the law, Plut., NTest.

div1.head: νομοθεσία
div1.sense: lawgiving, legislation, Plat.

div1.head: νομοθετέω
div1.sense: to make law, Plat., Xen., etc.:— Mid. to make laws for oneself, frame laws, Plat.
trans. to ordain by law, τι Plat., etc.:—Pass., impers., περὶ ταῦτα οὕτω σφι νενομοθέτηται it hath been so ordained by law, Hdt.

div1.head: νομοθέτημα
div1.sense: a law, ordinance, Plat.

div1.head: νομοθέτης
div1.sense: a lawgiver, Thuc., Plat., etc.
at Athens, the Nomothetae were a committee of the dicasts charged with the revision of the laws, Dem.

div1.head: νομοθετητέος
div1.sense: to be settled by law, Plat.
trans. one must ordain by law, Arist.

div1.head: νομοθετικός
div1.sense: of or for a lawgiver or legislation, Plat.: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) legislation, Plat.
of persons, fitted for legislation, Arist.

div1.head: νομόνδε
div1.sense: to pasture, Hom.

div1.head: νόμος
div1.sense: anything assigned, a usage, custom, law, ordinance, Lat. institutum, Hes.; νόμος πάντων βασιλεύς custom is lord of all, Pind. ap. Hdt.; κατὰ νόμον according to custom or law, Hes., Hdt., Attic; poet. κὰν νόμον Pind.:— παρὰ νόμον contrary to law, Aesch.:—dat. νόμῳ by custom, conventionally, opp. to φύσει, Hdt., Arist.:—at Athens νόμοι were Solon.ʼs laws, those of Draco being called θεσμοί.
ἐν χειρῶν νόμῳ by the law of force, in the fight or scuffle, Hdt.; ἐν χειρὸς νόμῳ in actual warfare, Arist.; also, ἐς χειρῶν νόμον ἀπικέσθαι to come to blows, Hdt.
a musical mode or strain, Aesch., Plat., etc.; νόμοι κιθαρῳδικοί Ar.
a song sung in honour of some god, Hdt.; νόμοι πολεμικοί war- tunes, Thuc.

div1.head: νομός
div1.sense: a feeding-place for cattle, pasture, Hom.; ν. ὕλης a woodland pasture, Od.
herbage, Hhymn.:—generally, food, Hes., Ar.
metaph., ἐπέων πολὺς νομός a wide range for words, Il.
an abode allotted or assigned to one, a district, province, Pind., Soph., etc.; νομὸν ἔχειν to have oneʼs dwelling-place, Hdt., Ar.
one of the districts into which Egypt was divided, Hdt., etc.; applied also to other provinces, Hdt.

div1.head: νομοφύλαξ
div1.sense: a guardian of the laws, Plat.

div1.head: νοόπληκτος
div1.sense: palsying the mind, Anth.

div1.head: νόος
div1.sense: mind, perception, Hom., etc.; νόῳ heedfully, Od.; παρὲκ νόον senselessly, Il.; σὺν νόῳ wisely, Hdt.; νόῳ λαβεῖν τι to apprehend it, Hdt.; νόῳ ἔχειν to keep in mind, Hdt.
νοῦν ἔχειν means
to have sense, be sensible, Soph., Ar., etc.; περισσὰ πράσσειν οὐκ ἔχει νοῦν οὐδένα to aim too high has no sense, Soph.
to have oneʼs mind directed to something, ἄλλοσʼ ὄμμα, θἀτέρᾳ δὲ νοῦν ἔχειν Soph.; δεῦρο νοῦν ἔχε Eur.
the mind, heart, χαῖρε νόῳ Od.; so, νόος ἔμπεδος, ἀπηνής Hom.; ἐκ παντὸς νόου with all his heart and soul, Hdt., etc.
oneʼs mind, purpose, τί σοι ἐν νόῳ ἐστὶ ποιεῖν; what do you intend to do? Hdt.; ἐν νόῳ ἔχειν, c. inf., to intend, Hdt.; νόον τελεῖν Il.
the sense or meaning of a word or speech, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: νοσακερός
div1.sense: liable to sickness, sickly, Arist.

div1.head: νοσερός
div1.sense: ν. κοίτη a bed of sickness, Eur.:—adv., νοσερῶς ἔχειν τὸ σῶμα Arist.

div1.head: νοσέω
div1.sense: to be sick, ill, to ail, whether in body or mind, Hdt., Attic; τῆς πόλεως οὔπω νενοσηκυίας not yet having suffered from the plague, Thuc.; ν. ὀφθαλμούς to be affected in the eyes, Plat.; τὸ νοσοῦν, νόσος, Soph.:—also of things, γῆ νοσεῖ Xen.
of passion, ν. μάτην to be mad, Soph.; θολερῷ χειμῶνι νοσήσας Soph.
generally, to be in an unsound state, to suffer, νοσεῖ τὰ τῶν θεῶν Eur.; ν. τι τῶν ἀπορρήτων κακῶν Eur.:—of states, to suffer from faction, be in disorder, Hdt.

div1.head: νοσηλεία
div1.sense: care of the sick, nursing, Plut.
(from Pass.) matter discharged from a sore, Soph.

div1.head: νοσηλεύω
div1.sense: to tend a sick person, Babr.

div1.head: νόσημα
div1.sense: a sickness, disease, plague, Soph., etc.
metaph. disease, affliction, Aesch., Plat.
of disorder in a state, Plat., etc.

div1.head: νοσηρός
div1.sense: diseased, unhealthy, Xen.

div1.head: νόσος
div1.sense: sickness, disease, malady, Hom., etc.
generally, distress, misery, suffering, sorrow, evil, Hes., Trag.
disease of mind, Trag.; θεία ν., i. e. madness, Soph.
of states, disorder, sedition, Plat.
a plague, bane, of a whirlwind, Soph.

div1.head: νοσοτροφία
div1.sense: care of the sick, Plat.

div1.head: νοστέω
div1.sense: to come or go back, return, esp. to oneʼs home or country, Hom., Soph., etc.
to return safe, to escape, Il., etc.

div1.head: νόστιμος
div1.sense: belonging to a return, ν. ἦμαρ the day of return, i. e. the return itself, Od.; so, ν. φάος Aesch.
able or likely to return, alive, safe, Lat. salvus, Od.
of plants, yielding a return, productive, τὸ ἐν σοι νοστιμώτατον what was most flourishing in you, Luc.

div1.head: νόστος
div1.sense: a return home or homeward, Hom.; c. gen. objecti, νόστος Ἀχαιΐδος his chance of returning to Greece, Od.; νόστον γαίης Φαιήκων thy way to the land of the Phaeacians, Od.
generally, travel, journey, ἐπὶ φορβῆς ν. a journey after (i. e. in search of) food, Soph.; ν. πρὸς Ἴλιον Eur.

div1.head: νοσφίζομαι
div1.sense: to turn oneʼs back upon a person, to turn away, shrink back, Hom.
to turn away from a person, c. gen., Od.
c. acc. to forsake, abandon, Hom., Soph.

after Hom., in Act., Attic fut. νοσφιῶ: aor1 ἐνόσφισα:— to set apart or aloof, to separate, remove, Eur.:—metaph., ν. τινὰ βίου to separate him from life, i. e. kill him, Soph.; so, ν. τινά alone, Aesch.
to deprive, rob, τινά τι one of a thing, Pind.; also, τινά τινος Aesch., Eur.
Mid. to put aside for oneself, to appropriate, purloin, Xen.:— ν. ἀπὸ τῆς τιμῆς to appropriate part of the price, NTest.
but the Mid. is also just like the Act., to deprive, rob, Eur.

div1.head: νόσφι
div1.etym: before a vowel or metri grat. -φιν, though may also be elided
div1.sense: as adv. of Place, aloof, apart, afar, away, Hom.; ν. ἰδών having looked aside, Od.; νόσφιν ἀπό aloof from, Il.; νόσφιν ἤ . ., like πλὴν ἤ . . , besides, except, Theocr.
as prep. aloof or away from, far from, Hom., Hes.
without, forsaken or unaided by, Hom., Aesch.
of mind or disposition, νόσφιν Ἀχαιῶν βουλεύειν apart from the Achaians, i. e. of a different way of thinking, Il.; ν. Δήμητρος, Lat. clam Cerere, without her knowledge, Hhymn.
beside, except, νόσφι Ποσειδάωνος Od.; νόσφʼ Ὠκεανοῖο Il.

div1.head: νοσώδης
div1.sense: sickly, diseased, ailing, Plat., etc.
act. pestilential, baneful, Eur.

div1.head: νοτερός
div1.sense: wet, damp, moist, Eur.; χειμὼν ν. a storm of rain, Thuc.

div1.head: νοτία
div1.sense: wet, νοτίαι εἰαριναί spring rains, Il.

div1.head: νοτίζω
div1.sense: to wet:—Pass. to be wetted or wet, Plat., Anth.

div1.head: νότιος
div1.sense: wet, moist, damp, Il., Aesch.:— ἐν νοτίῳ, i. e. the open sea, Od.
southern, ν. θάλασσα, i. e. the Indian ocean, Hdt.

div1.head: νοτίς
div1.sense: moisture, wet, Eur.

div1.head: νότος
div1.sense: the south or south-west wind, Lat. Auster, Od., Hdt., etc.
Notus is personified as god of the S. wind, Hes.
the south or south-west quarter, πρὸς νότον τῆς Λήμνου Hdt.; τὸ πρὸς ν. τῆς πόλεως Thuc.

div1.head: νουβυστικός
div1.sense: choke-full of sense, clever: adv. -κῶς, Ar.

div1.head: νουθετέω
div1.sense: to put in mind, to admonish, warn, advise, Hdt., Aesch., etc.;—c. dupl. acc., τοιαῦτʼ ἄνολβον ἄνδρʼ ἐνουθέτει Soph.:—Pass., Soph., etc.

div1.head: νουθέτημα
div1.sense: admonition, warning, Aesch., Eur., etc.; τἀμὰ νουθετήματα given to me, Soph.

div1.head: νουθέτησις
div1.sense: admonition, warning, Eur., Plat., etc.

div1.head: νουθετητέος
div1.sense: to be admonished, Eur.
νουθετητέον, one must warn, Arist.

div1.head: νουθετητικός
div1.sense: monitory, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: νουμηνία
div1.sense: the new moon, the first of the month, Pind., Ar.; ν. κατὰ σελήνην, to denote the true new moon, as opp. to the νουμηνία of the calendars, Hdt., Ar., etc.

div1.head: νουνέχεια
div1.sense: good sense, discretion, Polyb.

div1.head: νουνεχής
div1.sense: with understanding, sensible, discreet, Polyb. adv. -χῶς, Polyb.

div1.head: νυγμή
div1.sense: a pricking, puncture, Plut.

div1.head: νυκτεγερτέω
div1.sense: to watch by night, Plut.

div1.head: νυκτέλιος
div1.sense: nightly, name of Bacchus, from his nightly festivals, Anth.

div1.head: νυκτερέτης
div1.sense: one who rows by night, Anth.

div1.head: νυκτερευτικός
div1.sense: fit for hunting by night, Xen.

div1.head: νυκτερεύω
div1.sense: to pass the night, Xen.: of soldiers, to keep watch by night, bivouac, Xen.

div1.head: νυκτερήσιος
div1.sense: nightly, Ar.

div1.head: νυκτερινός
div1.sense: by night, nightly, Lat. nocturnus, Ar.; ν. γενέσθαι to happen by night, Ar.

div1.head: νυκτερίς
div1.sense: a bat, Lat. vespertilio, Od., Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: νυκτερωπός
div1.sense: appearing by night, Eur.

div1.head: νυκτηγορέω
div1.sense: to summon by night, Eur.; so in Mid., Aesch.

div1.head: νυκτηγορία
div1.sense: a nightly summons, Eur.

div1.head: νυκτηρεφής
div1.sense: covered by night, murky, Aesch.

div1.head: νυκτίβρομος
div1.sense: roaring by night, Eur.

div1.head: νυκτικλέπτης
div1.sense: thief of the night, Anth.

div1.head: νυκτικόραξ
div1.sense: the night-raven, Anth.

div1.head: νυκτιλαθραιοφάγος
div1.sense: eating secretly by night, Anth.

div1.head: νυκτιλάλος
div1.sense: nightly-sounding, Anth.

div1.head: νυκτιλαμπής
div1.sense: illumined by night alone, i. e. murky, dark, Simon.

div1.head: νύκτιος
div1.sense: nightly, Anth.

div1.head: νυκτιπαταιπλάγιος
div1.sense: nightly-roaming-to-and-fro, Anth.

div1.head: νυκτίπλαγκτος
div1.sense: making to wander by night, rousing from bed, Aesch.; ν. εὐνή a restless, uneasy bed, Aesch.

div1.head: νυκτίπλανος
div1.sense: roaming by night, Luc.

div1.head: νυκτιπόλος
div1.sense: roaming by night, Eur.

div1.head: νυκτίσεμνος
div1.sense: solemnised by night, Aesch.

div1.head: νυκτιφανής
div1.sense: shining by night, Anth.
with shades dark as night, Anth.

div1.head: νυκτίφαντος
div1.sense: appearing by night, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: νυκτίφοιτος
div1.sense: night-roaming, Aesch.

div1.head: νυκτιφρούρητος
div1.sense: watching by night, Aesch.

div1.head: νυκτοθήρας
div1.sense: a night-hunter, Xen.

div1.head: νυκτομαχέω
div1.sense: to fight by night, Plut.

div1.head: νυκτομαχία
div1.sense: a night- battle, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: νυκτοπεριπλάνητος
div1.sense: roaming about by night, Ar.

div1.head: νυκτοπορέω
div1.sense: to travel by night, Xen.

div1.head: νυκτοπορία
div1.sense: a night-journey, night-march, Polyb.

div1.head: νυκτοφυλακέω
div1.sense: to keep guard by night, ν. τὰ ἔξω to watch the outer parts by night, Xen.

div1.head: νυκτοφύλαξ
div1.sense: a night-watcher, warder, Lat. excubitor, Xen.

div1.head: νυκτῷον
div1.sense: a temple of Night, Luc.

div1.head: νύκτωρ
div1.sense: by night, Hes., Soph., etc.

div1.head: νυμφαγωγέω
div1.sense: to lead the bride to the bridegroomʼs house, γάμους ν. to court a marriage, Plut.

div1.head: νυμφαγωγός
div1.sense: leader of the bride, Eur.

div1.head: νύμφαιον
div1.sense: a temple of the nymphs, Plut.

div1.head: νυμφαῖος
div1.sense: of or sacred to the nymphs, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: νυμφεῖος
div1.sense: of a bride, bridal, nuptial, Pind., Eur.
as Subst.,
νυμφεῖον (sc. δῶμα) , the bridechamber, Soph.
νυμφεῖα (sc. ἱερά), τά, nuptial rites, marriage, Soph.
νυμφεῖα τοῦ σαυτοῦ τέκνου thine own sonʼs bride, Soph.

div1.head: νύμφευμα
div1.sense: marriage, espousal, Soph., Eur.
in sg. the person married, καλὸν ν. τινι "a good match for him, " Eur.

div1.head: νυμφευτήριος
div1.sense: nuptial, Eur.

div1.head: νυμφευτής
div1.sense: one who escorts the bride to the bridegroomʼs house, negotiator of a marriage, Plat.
a bridegroom, husband, Eur.

div1.head: νυμφεύτρια
div1.sense: a brideʼs-maid, Ar.

div1.head: νυμφεύω
div1.sense: to lead the bride, to give in marriage, betroth, Eur.
to marry, of the woman, Lat. nubere, Soph.; but also of the man, Lat. ducere, Eur.; of both parties, νυμφεύετʼ, εὖ πράσσοιτε Eur.
Pass. c. fut. mid. νυμφεύσομαι; aor1 mid. et pass. ἐνυμφευσάμην, ἐνυμφεύθην:— to be given in marriage, marry, of the woman, Eur.; ν. ἔκ τινος to be wedded by him, Eur.
in Mid. of the man, to take to wife, Eur.

div1.head: νύμφη
div1.sense: Epic voc. νύμφα: Doric νύμφᾱ:—, a young wife, bride, Lat. nupta, Il., Trag.
any married woman, Od., Eur.
a marriageable maiden, Il., Hes.
= Lat. nurus, daughter-in-law, NTest.

as prop. name, a Nymph, Hom.; θεαὶ Νύμφαι Il.; distinguished by special names, spring- nymphs being Ναϊάδες, sea- nymphs Νηρηίδες, tree- nymphs Δρυάδες, Ἁμαδρυάδες, mountain- nymphs ὀρεστιάδες, ὀρεάδες, meadow- nymphs λειμωνιάδες.
persons in a state of rapture, as seers and poets, were said to be caught by the Nymphs, νυμφόληπτοι, Lat. lymphatici.
the chrysalis, or pupa of moths, Anth.

div1.head: νυμφίδιος
div1.sense: of a bride, bridal, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: νυμφίος
div1.sense: a bridegroom, one lately married, Hom., etc.; in pl., τοῖς νεωστὶ νυμφίοις to the bridal pair, Eur.

div1.head: νυμφίος2
div1.sense: bridal, Pind.

div1.head: νυμφογενής
div1.sense: nymph-born, Anth.

div1.head: νυμφόκλαυτος
div1.sense: to be deplored by wives, Aesch.

div1.head: νυμφοκομέω
div1.sense: to dress a bride, Anth.
intr. to dress oneself as a bride, Eur.

div1.head: νυμφοκόμος
div1.sense: dressing a bride:—generally, bridal, Eur.

div1.head: νυμφόληπτος
div1.sense: caught by nymphs, Plat.

div1.head: νυμφοστολέω
div1.sense: to escort the bride, Anth.

div1.head: νυμφότιμος
div1.sense: honouring the bride: μέλος ν. the bridal song, Aesch.

div1.head: νυμφών
div1.sense: the bridechamber, NTest.

div1.head: νῦν δή
div1.sense: stronger form of νῦν, with pres. now, even now, Plat.
with past tenses, just now, ἃ νῦν δὴ ἐγὼ ἔλεγον Plat.

div1.head: νυνδί
div1.sense: familiar Attic for νυνὶδέ, Ar.

div1.head: νυνί
div1.etym: Attic form of νῦν, strengthd. by -ῑ demonstr.
div1.sense: now, at this moment, Dem., Aeschin.

div1.head: νυνμενί
div1.sense: familiar Attic for νυνὶ μέν, Ar.

div1.head: νῦν
div1.sense: now at this very time, Lat. nunc, οἳ νῦν βροτοί εἰσι mortals who now live, such as they are now, Il.; so in Attic, οἱ νῦν ἄνθρωποι men of the present day; τὸ νῦν the present time, Plat.;— τὰ νῦν (often written τανῦν) used simply like νῦν, Hdt., Attic
also of what is just past, just now, but now, Hom., Soph.
now, i. e. as it is, as the case now stands, Thuc.; so, καὶ νῦν even in this case, Xen.
besides the sense of Time, the enclit. νυν, νυ denotes
immediate sequence of one thing upon another, then, thereupon, thereafter, Hom.
also by way of Inference, then, therefore, Il., etc.
used to strengthen a command, δεῦρό νυν quick then! Il.; εἶά νυν, etc.; φέρε νυν, ἄγε νυν, σπεῦδέ νυν, σίγα νυν, etc., Xen.:—also to strengthen a question, τίς νυν; τί νυν; who then? what then? Xen.

div1.head: νύξ
div1.sense: Lat. nox, night, i. e. either the night-season or a night, Hom., Hes., etc.; νυκτός by night, Lat. noctu, Od., Attic; νυκτὸς ἔτι while it was still night, Hdt.; ν. τῆσδε Soph.; ἄκρας ν. at deadof night, Soph.; also, νυκτί Hdt., Soph.;— νύκτα the night long, the livelong night, Hom.; νύκτας by nights, Hom.;— μέσαι νύκτες midnight, Plat.

with Preps., ἀνὰ νύκτα by night, Il.; διὰ νύκτα Od.; εἰς νύκτα, εἰς τὴν ν. towards night, Xen.; ὑπὸ νύκτα just at night-fall, Thuc., Xen.; διὰ νυκτός in the course of the night, Plat.; ἐκ νυκτός just after night-fall, Xen.; πόρρω τῶν νυκτῶν far into the night, Xen.:— ἐπὶ νυκτί by night, Il.; ἐν νυκτί, ἐν τῇ ν. Aesch., etc.
in pl., also, the watches of the night, Pind., Plat.:—the Greeks divided the night into three watches, Hom., etc.
the dark of night, Hom.
the night of death, Hom.; ν. Ἄιδης τε Soph.
Νύξ as prop. n., the goddess of Night, daughter of Chaos, Il., Hes.
the quarter of night, i. e. the West, Hes.

div1.head: νυός
div1.sense: a daughter-in-law, Hom.; in wider sense, any female connected by marriage, Il.
a bride, wife, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: ν
div1.sense: Ν, ν, νῦ, τό, indecl., thirteenth letter of Greek alphabet; as numeral, νʹ = 50, but ͵ν = 50,000. ν is the dental or palatal liquid, corresponding with the mute δ. Dialectic changes,
Doric, ν represents λ, v. Λ λ. 2.
Attic and Doric for μ, v. Μ μ. II. 2.
Euphonic changes:
into γ before the palatals γ κ χ, and before ξ, as ἔγγονος ἔγκαιρος ἐγχώριος ἐγξέω etc.
into μ before the labials β π φ, and before ψ, as σύμβιος συμπότης συμφυής ἔμψυχος; likewise before μ. as ἐμμανής.
into λ, before λ, as ἐλλείπω συλλαμβάνω.
into ρ before ρ, as συρράπτω· in compds. of ἐν ν sometimes remains, as ἔνρυθμος.
into ς before ς, as σύσσιτος πάσσοφος.

the so-called νῦ ἐφελκυστικόν is found with dat. pl. in σι, as ἀνδράσιν; 3rd pl. of verbs in σι, as εἰλήφασιν; 3rd sg.in -ε, -ι, as ἔκτανεν δείκνυσιν: the local termin. -σι, as Ἀθήνῃσι Ὀλυμπίασι; the Epic. termin. φι, as ὀστεόφιν; the numeral εἴκοσι; the Advs. νόσφι, πέρυσι; the enclit. Particles κέ and νύ. This ν was mostly used to avoid a hiatus where a vowel follows.

div1.head: Νῦσα
div1.sense: name of several hills sacred to Bacchus, Hhymn., etc.;—adj. Νύσιος, η, ον, Hhymn.; Νυσήιος, Ar.

div1.head: νύσσα
div1.sense: like Lat. meta, the name of two posts in the ἱππόδρομος:
the turning-post, so placed that the chariots driving up the right side of the course, turned round it, and returned by the left side (cf. καμπτήρ) , Il.
the starting post, which was also the winning post, Hom.

div1.head: νύσσω
div1.sense: to touch with a sharp point, to prick, spur, pierce, Il., Hes.; ἀγκῶνι νύξας having nudged him with the elbow, Od.; ν. γνώμην to prick it (and see what is in it), Ar.

div1.head: νυστάζω
div1.sense: to nod in sleep, to nap, slumber, Xen., Plat.
to be sleepy, napping, Lat. dormito, Ar., Plat.
to hang the head, Anth.

div1.head: νυστακτής
div1.sense: one that nods, nodding, Ar.

div1.head: νύχευμα
div1.sense: a nightly watch, Lat. pervigilium, Eur.

div1.head: νυχεύω
div1.sense: to watch the night through, to pass the night, Eur.

div1.head: νυχθήμερον
div1.sense: a night and a day, NTest.

div1.head: νύχιος
div1.sense: nightly, i. e.
of persons, doing a thing by night, Hes., Aesch., etc.
of things, happening by night, Soph., Eur.
of places, dark as night, gloomy, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: νωδός
div1.sense: toothless, Ar., Theocr.

div1.head: νωδυνία
div1.sense: ease from pain, Theocr.
an anodyne, Pind.

div1.head: νώδυνος
div1.sense: without pain, Pind.
act. soothing pain, anodyne, Soph.

div1.head: νώθεια
div1.sense: sluggishness, dulness, Plat., etc.

div1.head: νωθής
div1.sense: sluggish, slothful, torpid, epith. of the ass, Il., Eur., etc.
of the understanding, dull, stupid, νωθέστερος somewhat dull, Hdt.

div1.head: νωθρός
div1.sense: sluggish, slothful, torpid, Plat.

div1.head: νωΐτερος
div1.sense: of or from us two, Hom.

div1.head: νωλεμές
div1.sense: without pause, unceasingly, continually, Hom.:—so, νωλεμέως, Il.; ν. ἐχέμεν to persevere, Il.; but, ν. κτείνοντο they were murdered without pause, i. e. one after the other, Od.

div1.head: νωμάω
div1.sense: to deal out, distribute, esp. food and drink at festivals, Hom.
(νέμω III. 2) to direct, guide, control,
of weapons, to handle, wield, sway the lance, shield, rudder, Hom.; so metaph., νώμα πηδαλίῳ πόλιν was steering it, Lat. gubernabat, Pind.; πᾶν ν. ἐπὶ τέρμα Aesch.
of the limbs, to ply nimbly, γούνατα νωμᾶν Il.; πόδα ν. Soph.; ν. ὀφρύν to move the brow, Aesch.
to revolve in the mind, Od.: to observe, watch, Hdt., Trag.

div1.head: νώνυμνος
div1.etym: Epic for νώνυμος, used when the penult. is to be long, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: νώνυμος
div1.sense: nameless, unknown, inglorious, Od., Aesch., Soph.
c. gen., Σαπφοῦς νώνυμος without the name of Sappho, i. e. without knowledge of her, Anth.

div1.head: νῶροψ
div1.sense: flashing, gleaming, of metal, Il.

div1.head: νωτάκμων
div1.sense: with mailed back, Batr.

div1.head: νωτιαῖος
div1.sense: of the back or spine, ν. ἄρθρα the spinal vertebrae, Eur.

div1.head: νωτίζω
div1.sense: to turn oneʼs back, Lat. terga dare, Eur.; c. acc. cogn., παλίσσυτον δράμημα νωτίσαι to turn about in backward course, Soph.
to cover the back of, τινά Eur.; πόντον νωτίσαι to skim the sea, Aesch.

div1.head: νώτισμα
div1.sense: that which covers the back, of wings, Eur.

div1.head: νῶτον
div1.sense: the back, Lat. tergum, Il.; often in pl., like Lat. terga, Hom.; τὰ νῶτα ἐντρέπειν, ἐπιστρέφειν to turn the back, i. e. flee, Hdt.; νῶτα δεῖξαι Plut.; κατὰ νώτου from behind, in rear, Hdt., Thuc.
metaph. any wide surface, ἐπʼ εὐρέα νῶτα θαλάσσης Hom.; of plains, Pind., Eur.
the back or ridge, of a hill, Pind., Eur.; of a chariot, Eur.

div1.head: νωτοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying on the back: as Subst. a beast of burthen, Xen.

div1.head: νωχελής
div1.sense: moving slowly and heavily, sluggish, Eur.

div1.head: νωχελία
div1.sense: laziness, sluggishness, Il.
